stages.title: Awareness
stages.description: Recognizing symptoms and starting your healthcare journey

substages.title: Symptom/Health Need
substages.description: When you first notice something is wrong
painPoints: Fear about what symptoms might mean
Discomfort with current condition

tips.title: Document your symptoms
tips.body: Keep a detailed log of when symptoms occur, their severity, and what makes them better or worse. This will help your doctor diagnose you more accurately.

tips.title: Don't panic
tips.body: Many symptoms have benign causes. Stay calm and seek professional medical advice rather than jumping to conclusions.

substages.title: Online Diagnosis/Dr. Google
painPoints: Information looks scary and overwhelming
Don't know where to start for reliable answers

tips.title: Use trusted medical sources
tips.body: Stick to reputable sites like Mayo Clinic, Cleveland Clinic, or WebMD. Avoid forums where non-professionals share anecdotes.

tips.title: Note questions for your doctor
tips.body: As you research, write down specific questions to ask a healthcare professional rather than self-diagnosing.

substages.title: Type of Facility/Specialist
substages.description: Determining what kind of care you need
painPoints: What type of doctor do I need?
What kind of facility/care should I go for?
Is it urgent?

tips.title: Know your care options
tips.body: Primary Care for general issues, Urgent Care for non-life-threatening urgent issues, ER for emergencies, Specialists for specific conditions.

tips.title: Call your primary care first
tips.body: Your PCP can guide you on the right type of specialist or facility. They may also provide a referral if needed.

substages.title: Locations: What is Near Me
painPoints: Can I get the care I need at this location?
How far do I need to travel?

tips.title: Check your insurance's provider directory
tips.body: Use your insurance website's 'Find a Doctor' tool to see in-network providers near you with their locations and services offered.

tips.title: Verify services before traveling
tips.body: Call ahead to confirm the location offers the specific services you need before making a long trip.

substages.title: Word of Mouth/Referrals
painPoints: The popular/best doctors aren't taking new patients

tips.title: Ask to be added to waitlists
tips.body: If your preferred doctor isn't accepting new patients, ask to be added to their waitlist. Spots often open up.

tips.title: Ask for multiple recommendations
tips.body: Get names of 3-5 doctors from trusted sources so you have backup options if your first choice isn't available.

substages.title: Website/Online Reviews
painPoints: Can I trust these ratings?

tips.title: Look for patterns in reviews
tips.body: Don't focus on single reviews. Look for consistent themes across many reviews about communication style, wait times, and bedside manner.

tips.title: Check multiple review sources
tips.body: Cross-reference reviews on Healthgrades, Vitals, Google, and your insurance provider's site for a fuller picture.

substages.title: Provider Search
substages.description: Finding doctors with the right expertise
painPoints: Does this doctor have expertise I need?
Will I be in good hands?
Will I like the doctor once I meet them?
What other doctors will I be billed for?

tips.title: Check credentials and specializations
tips.body: Look for board certification, years of experience, and any sub-specialties that match your condition.

tips.title: Schedule a consultation if possible
tips.body: Some practices offer brief meet-and-greet appointments to see if you're comfortable with the doctor before committing to treatment.

tips.title: Ask about the care team
tips.body: Find out who else you might see (nurse practitioners, physician assistants, residents) and how billing works for each.

substages.title: Insurance Coverage
painPoints: My plan isn't listed
Listings are out-of-date
What do I ask my insurance?

tips.title: Call both the provider AND your insurance
tips.body: Verify coverage from both sides. Ask the provider's office if they accept your specific plan, and call your insurance to confirm the provider is in-network.

tips.title: Get confirmation in writing
tips.body: Ask for written confirmation of coverage and keep it with your records in case of billing disputes later.

tips.title: Questions to ask your insurance
tips.body: Ask: Is this provider in-network? What's my copay/coinsurance? Do I need a referral? What's my deductible status?

stages.title: Access
stages.description: Scheduling and preparing for your appointment

substages.title: Self-Schedule (Online)
painPoints: Why don't some doctors schedule online?
How long will my wait be with this doctor?

tips.title: Call if online booking is limited
tips.body: Some doctors prefer to discuss symptoms before scheduling. If online options are limited, call the office for more availability.

tips.title: Ask about typical wait times
tips.body: When scheduling, ask both how far out appointments are booked AND how long the wait is once you arrive for your appointment.

substages.title: Call Center
painPoints: Long wait times on phone
Not the doctor I wanted
Is there a waitlist?

tips.title: Call at optimal times
tips.body: Call right when the office opens or during lunch hours (12-1pm) when call volumes are typically lower.

tips.title: Be specific about your doctor preference
tips.body: Clearly state which doctor you want to see and why. Ask about wait times for each available provider if your first choice isn't available soon.

tips.title: Always ask about waitlists
tips.body: If your preferred time/doctor isn't available, ask to be put on a cancellation list and ensure they have your best contact number.

substages.title: Pricing Transparency/Estimates
painPoints: What CPT code should I look up?
Insurance can't tell me my out-of-pocket cost

tips.title: Ask the office for procedure codes
tips.body: When scheduling, ask what CPT codes will likely be used for your visit so you can get accurate pricing estimates.

tips.title: Request a cost estimate
tips.body: Many providers are now required to provide good-faith estimates. Ask the billing department for a written estimate before your appointment.

tips.title: Understand your insurance terms
tips.body: Know your deductible, copay, coinsurance, and out-of-pocket max. This helps you estimate costs even without exact amounts.

substages.title: Prior Authorizations
painPoints: When is a prior authorization needed?
Will this delay anything? What if denied?
Should I do anything?

tips.title: Ask who handles prior auth
tips.body: Clarify whether the doctor's office or you are responsible for submitting prior authorization. Most offices handle this, but confirm.

tips.title: Request rush processing if urgent
tips.body: If your procedure is time-sensitive, ask your doctor to mark the prior auth as urgent and provide supporting documentation.

tips.title: Have a backup plan
tips.body: Ask your doctor about alternatives if the prior auth is denied, and understand your appeal rights.

substages.title: Reminders/Advance Paperwork
painPoints: Questions will probably be asked again
Directions/parking unclear

tips.title: Complete forms in advance
tips.body: Even if you'll be asked again, complete advance paperwork thoroughly. It becomes part of your medical record and saves time at check-in.

tips.title: Call for specific directions
tips.body: Don't rely solely on GPS. Call the office for specific parking instructions, building entrance details, and where to check in.

tips.title: Set multiple reminders
tips.body: Set reminders for 1 week before (to prepare), 1 day before (to confirm), and 2 hours before (to leave on time).

substages.title: MyChart Signup
painPoints: Do I already have an account?
Do I need a new MyChart for each doctor?
Current process confusing - code from front desk? Credit check?

tips.title: Check if you already have an account
tips.body: Try the 'Forgot Password' feature with your email or phone number to see if you already have an account before creating a new one.

tips.title: Understand MyChart systems
tips.body: Different health systems use different MyChart instances. You may need separate accounts for different hospital networks.

tips.title: Activate your account early
tips.body: Sign up for your patient portal as soon as possible after scheduling. You'll need it for forms, results, and communication.

substages.title: Preparing for Your Appointment
painPoints: What do I need to bring?
What if I don't remember questions for the doctor?
Will doctor have all my records from other doctors?
How will I get there? Can I drive myself?
Will I need to mask/other onsite regulations?
Can I/should I bring a friend?
What if I need a translator?

tips.title: Create a preparation checklist
tips.body: Bring: Insurance card, photo ID, medication list, symptom log, list of questions, records from other doctors, and a notebook for notes.

tips.title: Write down your questions
tips.body: List your top 3-5 questions in priority order. Start with the most important in case time runs short.

tips.title: Request records in advance
tips.body: Contact your other doctors 1-2 weeks before your appointment to have records sent directly to your new provider.

tips.title: Arrange transportation
tips.body: If you might receive sedation, dilated eyes, or affecting treatment, arrange for a driver beforehand. Many offices won't proceed without one.

tips.title: Check current facility policies
tips.body: Call ahead to ask about masking requirements, visitor policies, and any other COVID-related or facility-specific rules.

tips.title: Bring a support person
tips.body: A friend or family member can help remember instructions, ask questions you forgot, and provide emotional support. Check visitor policies first.

tips.title: Request interpreter services
tips.body: Call at least 48-72 hours before your appointment to arrange for a professional medical interpreter if needed. This is often a free service.

substages.title: Traveling to Appointment
substages.description: Getting to your appointment on time
painPoints: Which campus was this at?
Where do I park?
Which building do I go in?
If I'm running late, who do I call?
How late can I be before they cancel?

tips.title: Verify location details
tips.body: Confirm the exact address, building name, and floor the day before. Large medical centers often have multiple campuses.

tips.title: Plan to arrive 15-20 minutes early
tips.body: This gives you time to park, find the right building, check in, and complete any last-minute paperwork without stress.

tips.title: Save the office number in your phone
tips.body: If you're running late, call as soon as you know. Most offices can accommodate 10-15 minute delays if you communicate.

tips.title: Ask about late arrival policies
tips.body: When scheduling, ask how late you can be before they cancel. Policies vary from 10-30 minutes typically.

substages.title: Check-in/Registration
painPoints: Paperwork has same questions as online
Electronic signature but no text/copy

tips.title: Request copies of all forms
tips.body: Ask for copies or photos of everything you sign. These are your rights as a patient, and you may need them for records or insurance.

tips.title: Review forms carefully
tips.body: Even if questions seem repetitive, read carefully. Sometimes forms ask slightly different questions or update previous information.

tips.title: Ask about electronic access
tips.body: Ask if forms you signed electronically will be available in your patient portal for future reference.

substages.title: Wait & Rooming
substages.description: Waiting room and being taken back
painPoints: Long waiting times
Being around other sick people
Asked name/DOB/form questions again
Wasn't given time to finish the whole form
Weight/height/BP - heavier than home scale with clothes, taking shoes off inconvenient, nowhere to put stuff in pockets

tips.title: Bring something to do
tips.body: Pack a book, download entertainment, or bring work. Wait times can vary, so be prepared to wait comfortably.

tips.title: Practice good hygiene
tips.body: Wash hands or use sanitizer after checking in. Avoid touching your face. Consider wearing a mask in crowded waiting areas.

tips.title: Understand verification is for safety
tips.body: Staff repeatedly verify your name and DOB to ensure they have the right patient and records. This protects you from medical errors.

tips.title: Ask for more time if needed
tips.body: If you need more time to complete forms, let the staff know. Your thorough answers are more important than speed.

tips.title: Wear easy-to-remove layers
tips.body: Wear slip-on shoes and keep valuables in a bag rather than pockets for easier vitals check. Wear layers you can easily remove if needed.

substages.title: Exam Room/Procedure
painPoints: Doctor didn't look at form - so why did I do it?
Is the doctor judging me - for my weight/gender/skin color/questions/anxiety?
Doctor doesn't seem to understand my symptoms or believe me
Short appointment time
Hard to follow everything doctor said
I forgot to ask some questions

tips.title: Advocate for yourself
tips.body: If you feel unheard, say 'I don't feel like my concerns are being addressed' or 'Can we go back to my main symptom?' It's your right to be heard.

tips.title: Take notes during the visit
tips.body: Write down key points, diagnoses, and instructions as the doctor speaks. Or ask if you can record the conversation on your phone.

tips.title: Ask for clarification
tips.body: If something is unclear, say 'Can you explain that in simpler terms?' or 'Can you repeat that?' Good doctors want you to understand.

tips.title: Prioritize your top concerns
tips.body: Start with your most important issue. Say 'My biggest concern today is...' to ensure it gets addressed even if time is short.

tips.title: Ask about next steps before leaving
tips.body: Before the doctor leaves, ask: What's the diagnosis? What's the treatment plan? When should I follow up? What warning signs should I watch for?

tips.title: Request a different provider if needed
tips.body: If you consistently feel judged or dismissed, you have the right to request a different doctor. Your comfort and trust matter.

substages.title: After-Visit Summary (AVS) & Instructions
painPoints: I didn't notice or read what they gave me
I lost the AVS papers
I need help with some of the steps
I did some things but forgot others
I don't like what my doctor recommended - can I ignore/push back?
I want a second opinion

tips.title: Review AVS before leaving
tips.body: Read through your After-Visit Summary while still at the office. Ask questions about anything unclear before you go.

tips.title: Take a photo of all paperwork
tips.body: Photograph your AVS and any prescriptions or instructions immediately. This way you have a backup if you lose the paper copy.

tips.title: Access AVS in your patient portal
tips.body: Most AVS documents are also uploaded to your patient portal within 24 hours. Check there if you've lost your paper copy.

tips.title: Create a care task list
tips.body: Convert your AVS instructions into a checklist with deadlines. Check off each item as you complete it.

tips.title: Discuss concerns about treatment
tips.body: If you have doubts about the recommended treatment, message your doctor through the portal or call to discuss. Don't just ignore medical advice.

tips.title: Getting a second opinion
tips.body: You always have the right to a second opinion, especially for serious diagnoses or major procedures. Tell your doctor - most will support this.

substages.title: Labs/Scans
painPoints: Where do I go?
What labs will have my orders? Do I need paper?
Labs are closed/shorter hours
Online info on lab services not clear
I forget to get tested/need reminders

tips.title: Get clear lab instructions
tips.body: Before leaving your appointment, ask: Which lab location? Do I need an appointment? Any preparation needed (fasting, etc.)? How will I get results?

tips.title: Confirm orders are in the system
tips.body: Call the lab before you go to confirm they have your orders. Bring a paper copy of the order just in case.

tips.title: Check lab hours and services
tips.body: Lab hours often differ from clinic hours. Check hours, location, and whether walk-ins are accepted before you go.

tips.title: Schedule labs immediately
tips.body: Book your lab appointment right away or add a specific date to your calendar. Set phone reminders to follow through.

tips.title: Prepare properly for tests
tips.body: Follow all fasting and preparation instructions carefully. Improper preparation can lead to invalid results and having to repeat tests.

stages.title: Ongoing Care
stages.description: Follow-up and continuing your health journey

substages.title: Test Results
substages.description: Understanding your lab and scan results
painPoints: How long for results?
No doctor message with results
What are the next steps needed?

tips.title: Ask about results timeline
tips.body: When tests are ordered, ask when you should expect results and how you'll be notified (portal, phone call, etc.).

tips.title: Don't assume no news is good news
tips.body: If you haven't heard about results within the expected timeframe, follow up proactively. Results can sometimes get overlooked.

tips.title: Request explanation of results
tips.body: If results are posted without doctor comments, message your doctor asking what the results mean and what next steps are needed.

tips.title: Keep a results binder
tips.body: Print or save PDFs of all test results in chronological order. This helps track trends over time and is useful for new doctors.

substages.title: Billing / Explanations of Benefits
painPoints: Shocking cost
Confusing - what service was this for?
How do I check if these charges are right?
'Due now' is too soon
Surprise charge for a physical I thought was free
Surprise charge for doctors I don't remember meeting

tips.title: Review EOBs carefully
tips.body: Your Explanation of Benefits (EOB) from insurance comes before the bill. Review it to understand what was covered and what you'll owe.

tips.title: Match bills to services received
tips.body: Compare dates and service codes on bills with your visit records. Look up CPT codes online to understand what each charge represents.

tips.title: Question unclear charges immediately
tips.body: Call the billing department right away if you see charges that don't make sense. Errors are more common than you'd think.

tips.title: Request payment plans
tips.body: If you can't pay the full amount, call billing to set up a payment plan. Most offices offer interest-free payment options.

tips.title: Understand preventive visit billing
tips.body: Preventive visits are free, BUT if you discuss new problems or existing conditions, those can be billed separately. Ask beforehand what's covered.

tips.title: Know about facility fees and surprise doctors
tips.body: You may be charged for consulting physicians, anesthesiologists, or facility fees you weren't aware of. Ask about all potential charges upfront.

tips.title: Apply for financial assistance
tips.body: Many hospitals and clinics offer financial assistance programs for those who qualify. Ask the billing department about applications.

substages.title: Follow-up Scheduling / Specialty Referrals
painPoints: Referral taking forever - is it lost?
How do I follow up and check on referral status?
I forgot to schedule PCP follow-up
Out-of-network referral - will it be covered? Were med records sent?

tips.title: Schedule follow-ups before leaving
tips.body: If your doctor recommends a follow-up visit, schedule it before you leave the office or immediately when you get home.

tips.title: Track referral status actively
tips.body: Don't wait passively for referrals. Call both your doctor's office and the specialist after 3-5 business days to confirm the referral was sent and received.

tips.title: Get referral details in writing
tips.body: Ask for the specialist's name, phone number, and what records are being sent. This helps you follow up effectively.

tips.title: Verify out-of-network coverage first
tips.body: Before seeing an out-of-network specialist, call your insurance to understand coverage. Ask if there are in-network alternatives.

tips.title: Confirm record transfer
tips.body: Call the specialist's office a few days before your appointment to confirm they received your medical records from your referring doctor.

substages.title: Questions/New Symptoms/MyChart Messaging
substages.description: Communicating with your care team between visits
painPoints: How do I see notes my doctor took?
Follow-up questions not answered as quickly
How much can I ask my doctor via a message?
Will I be charged for this message? How much/how will I know?

tips.title: Access your medical records online
tips.body: Most states require doctors to share visit notes with patients. Look in your patient portal under 'Visit Notes' or 'Medical Records'.

tips.title: Understand message response times
tips.body: Most offices respond to portal messages within 2-3 business days. For urgent issues, call instead of messaging.

tips.title: Know what's appropriate for messaging
tips.body: Good for: follow-up questions, medication refills, test result clarification. NOT for: new urgent symptoms, emergencies, complex issues.

tips.title: Ask about message billing policies
tips.body: Some practices may bill for extensive message consultations. Ask your office about their policy for patient portal messages.

tips.title: Be clear and specific in messages
tips.body: Include relevant details, dates, and specific questions. Clear messages get better, faster responses.

substages.title: Preventive Reminders (Population Health/Health Equity)
substages.description: Staying on top of preventive care
painPoints: What preventive care do I need?
What extra risk factors do I have?
How do I know if I'm up to date on vaccinations?
Is there a new COVID vaccine? How do I know when to get another?
Do I need a physical if I just saw my doctor?
What can I ask/get from an annual physical/wellness visit?

tips.title: Review preventive care guidelines
tips.body: Check CDC and USPSTF guidelines for recommended screenings based on your age, gender, and risk factors. Discuss with your doctor.

tips.title: Know your personal risk factors
tips.body: Understand your family history, lifestyle factors, and any chronic conditions. These affect what screenings and preventive care you need.

tips.title: Keep a vaccination record
tips.body: Maintain a personal record of all vaccinations with dates. Your patient portal usually has this info, but keep your own copy too.

tips.title: Stay informed about vaccine updates
tips.body: Sign up for CDC email updates or follow their social media for current vaccine recommendations, especially for flu and COVID-19.

tips.title: Annual wellness visits vs sick visits
tips.body: Annual physicals focus on prevention and screening. Even if you recently saw your doctor for illness, you should still get your annual wellness visit.

tips.title: Maximize your wellness visit
tips.body: Use your annual physical to discuss: screening tests needed, medication reviews, lifestyle changes, family history updates, and any health concerns.

tips.title: Set up annual reminders
tips.body: Add recurring calendar reminders for annual physicals, dental cleanings, eye exams, and other regular preventive care.

metadata.source: Patient Journey & Pain Points by Andrew Varyu
